[[Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)|Croix de guerre 1914–1918]] with palm[[Mentioned in Despatches]] |relations= |laterwork= }} Colonel '''Marie Augstin Gaston Cros''' (known as '''Gaston Cros''') (6 October 1861 – 10 May 1915) was a French army officer and archaeologist. He was born in [[Alsace]] and was displaced when that territory was incorporated into the [[German Empire]]. He joined the [[French Army]] as a [[lieutenant]] and saw action in [[Tonkin]] before spending several years surveying in [[Tunisia]], receiving the honours of membership of Vietnamese and Tunisian orders and appointment as a chevalier of the [[Legion of Honour]]. In 1901 Cros was appointed head of the French archaeological expedition to [[Girsu]], [[Iraq]] to continue the work of [[Ernest de Sarzec]]. His work over the next five years included the tracing of the {{convert|32.5|ft}} thick city wall and for his work there received a letter of commendation from [[Gaston Doumergue]], the Minister of Fine Arts, and the award of the Golden Palms of the [[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]]. Promoted to [[lieutenant-colonel]], Cros served in the [[French protectorate of Morocco]] from 1913, seeing action in the [[Zaian War]]. Upon the outbreak of the [[First World War]] Cros was recalled to metropolitan France and fought in defence of [[Paris]] at the [[First Battle of the Marne]], leading an [[ad hoc]] unit of [[zouave]]s and [[tirailleur]]s. He was wounded and spent two days directing his troops from a horse-drawn carriage before he was forced to leave his command. On 15 September 1914 he was promoted to [[colonel]] and subsequently received command of the 2nd Moroccan Brigade which he led at the [[Battle of the Yser]] and the [[Second Battle of Artois]]. It was at Artois that he was killed in a German counter-attack. Cros' name is recorded alongside that of [[Colonel Pein]], who commanded the 1st Moroccan Brigade at Artois, on the [[Moroccan Division Memorial]] at [[Vimy]]. == Early life == Marie Augstin Gaston Cros was born at 2.00am on 6 October 1861 to Hippolyte Cros, a lawyer, and Marie Petronille Reine Scherb at [[Saverne]], [[Bas-Rhin]] in the [[Alsace]] region. After Alsace was incorporated into the [[German Empire]] after the [[Franco-Prussian War]] of 1871 Cros' family chose to retain their French nationality and moved to [[Lunéville]] in [[Meurthe-et-Moselle]].{{cite web|title=Legion of Honour records - page 14|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v014.htm|work=Base Léonore|publisher=Ministère de la Culture|accessdate=3 February 2013}} Cros volunteered for a five-year commission with the [[French Army]] on 25 October 1881 at [[Nancy, France|Nancy]]. Four days later he was enrolled into the [[Ecole Spéciale Militaire de Saint-Cyr]] as a cadet, from which he graduated on 1 October 1883, ranked 261 out of 342 in his class. Cros was commissioned into the [[128th Infantry Regiment (France)|128th Infantry Regiment]] as a [[sub-lieutenant]] and attended the L'Ecole du Tir (marksmanship school) in 1885 where he ranked 25th out of 76 participants. Cros transferred to the 4th [[Tonkinese Rifles]] on 3 June 1887 and saw active service in [[Tonkin]] (northern Vietnam) from 19 June 1887 to 14 September 1888, joining the [[105th Infantry Regiment (France)|105th Infantry Regiment]] as a [[lieutenant]] on 5 October 1887.{{cite web|title=Legion of Honour records - page 15|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v015.htm|work=Base Léonore|publisher=Ministère de la Culture|accessdate=3 February 2013}} He was awarded the [[Tonkin Expedition commemorative medal]] for his work in the country. On 25 January 1889 Cros transferred to the 4th [[Zouave]] Regiment and was on active service in [[Tunisia]] from 11 March 1889 to 27 April 1898. He was attached to the Army Geographic Service from 1891 to 1893, and made several topographical surveys of the Sahara desert. Cros was appointed a knight of the [[Order of the Dragon of Annam]] and a member of the Tunisian [[Order of Glory (Tunisia)|Order of Glory]] on 10 October 1889 in recognition of his service in Tonkin and Tunisia.{{cite web|title=Legion of Honour records - page 21|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v021.htm|work=Base Léonore|publisher=Ministère de la Culture|accessdate=3 February 2013}} He was promoted to [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]] on 10 July 1894 and became a chevalier of the [[Legion of Honour]] on 29 December 1896.{{cite web|title=Legion of Honour records - page 17|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v017.htm|work=Base Léonore|publisher=Ministère de la Culture|accessdate=3 February 2013}} Cros transferred to the [[39th Infantry Regiment (France)|39th Infantry Regiment]] on 5 April 1898 and served with them in [[Algeria]] from 11 November 1899 to 1 June 1900. == Archaeological work at Tello == [[File:Votive dog Louvre AO4349 n2.jpg|thumb|A [[votive]] dog excavated by Cros from Tello in 1904]] From December 1901 Cros was placed in charge of the French-led Tello Expedition to the archaeological site of [[Girsu]] in [[Iraq]]. He replaced the late [[Ernest de Sarzec]], the French consul of [[Basra]], who died in 1901 and had been excavating Tello since 1877, having initiated the rediscovery of the [[Sumer]]ian civilization. The appointment of a military man to this position might have been influenced by the revolt of the [[Muntafiq]] Arabs against the [[Ottoman Empire]] which created a hostile environment for the archaeologists.{{cite book| last = Potts| first = D.T. (ed.)| title = A Companion to the Archaeology of the Ancient Near East| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=12hCMwEACAAJ| year = 2012| publisher = John Wiley & Sons| location = Chichester| isbn = 978-1405189880| page = 58 }} Cros' knowledge of archaeology, like Sarzac's, came from a purely amateur interest in the subject though he had a thorough understanding of desert topography from his surveying days.{{cite journal|last=Caubet|first=Annie|title=The historical context of the Sumerian discoveries|journal=Museum International|date=May 2009|volume=63|issue=1-2|pages=74–80|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0033.2009.01678.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0033.2009.01678.x/abstract?deniedAccessCustomisedMessage=&userIsAuthenticated=false|accessdate=24 February 2013}}{{cite book|last=Suter|first=Claudia E.|title=Gudea's temple building: the representation of an early Mesopotamian ruler in text and image|year=2000|publisher=Styx|location=Groningen, Netherlands|isbn=90 5693 035 4|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3laWpjUkWLcC}} One of Cros' first acts was to move the site of the French camp nearer to the excavation area, having been previously situated an hours ride away.{{cite book| last = King| first = L.W.| last2 = Hall| first2 = H.R.| title = History Of Egypt Chaldea, Syria, Babylonia, And Assyria In The Light Of Recent Discovery| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=u3fqLifsTZ4C| year = 2008| publisher = Echo| location = Teddington, UK| isbn = 978-1-4068-2717-0| pages = 88–90 }} This made it less defensible and further from the water supply but he solved these problems by negotiating protection from the local Karagul Arabs and co-ordinating the construction of a new reservoir supplied with water by caravan convoys. [[File:Issue of barley rations.JPG|thumb|right|One of the [[Cuneiform]] Tello tablets]] Cros undertook numerous excavations at Tello producing significant numbers of artefacts, some dating from the earliest periods of Sumerian civilization. One of his achievements, considered his most important at Tello, was the tracing of the great city wall which was {{convert|32.5|ft|m}} thick.{{cite book|last=Baikie|first=James|title=Glamour of the Near East Excavation 1927|publisher=Kessinger|location=2003|page=233|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0FrtAuLgnuYC}}{{cite book|last=Baikie|first=James|title=The Life of the Ancient East: Being Some Chapters of the Romance of Modern Excavation 1923|year=2004|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|page=192|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NMfnjAft5PQC}} In 1903 he discovered a doorway in the vicinity of de Sarzac's famous cuniform tablets that provided evidence that the tablets were stored as part of a state administrative archive.{{cite book|last1=Cooper|first1=Jerold S.|last2=Schwartz|first2=Glenn M.|title=The Study of the Ancient Near East in the Twenty-first Century|date=1996|publisher=Eisenbrauns|page=84|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3hc1Yp0VcjoC}} During his time at Tello he remained nominally with the 39th Infantry Regiment, transferring to the [[80th Infantry Regiment (France)|80th Infantry Regiment]] on 17 February 1903. His archaeological work was recognised by promotion to [[chef de bataillon]] (roughly equivalent to major), in the [[116th Infantry Regiment (France)|116th Infantry Regiment]], on 24 June 1905 and by appointment as an officer of the Legion of Honour on 12 March 1906.{{cite web|title=Legion of Honour records - page 1|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v001.htm|work=Base Léonore|publisher=Ministère de la Culture|accessdate=3 February 2013}} Cros transferred to the [[33rd Infantry Regiment (France)|33rd Infantry Regiment]] on 25 May 1906 and to the [[5th Infantry Regiment (France)|5th Infantry Regiment]] on 22 December of that year. He left Tello after his posting to the 5th Regiment but returned in 1909 to conclude his research, for which he was commended by [[Gaston Doumergue]], the Minister of Fine Arts. His research, published in the book ''Nouvelles Fouilles de Tello'' (New Excavations at Tello) in 1911, was welcomed by the British [[Royal Asiatic Society]] as some of the most important on the subject of ancient Sumeria.{{cite journal|last=Pinches|first=T.G.|title=Notices of Books|journal=[[Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society]] | series = (New Series)|date=July 1912|volume=44|issue=3|pages=829–831|doi=10.1017/S0035869X00147598|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=5702040|accessdate=29 December 2012}} When Cros left Tello in 1909 the French government was unable to find a suitable successor.{{cite book| last = Potts| first = D.T.| title = A Companion to the Archaeology of the Ancient Near East (Google eBook)| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=12hCMwEACAAJ| year = 2012| publisher = John Wiley and Sons| location = Chichester, UK| isbn = 978-1-4051-8988-0| pages = 58–60 }} Cros received the Golden Palms of the [[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]] for his academic work. A replacement was eventually found in 1914 but the outbreak of war prevented his assuming the post and the next chief of the French mission wasn't appointed until 1928. Cros was later promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]] of the 1st Algerian [[Tirailleurs]]. In April 1913 he transferred to the 5th Algerian Tirailleurs and undertook expeditions in Western Morocco from May to August 1913 for which he was commended. He subsequently participated in the [[Zaian War]] under General [[Hubert Lyautey]], leading a column from [[Rabat]] to capture [[Khénifra]]. Other columns were led by Lieutenant-Colonel [[Henri Claudel]] from [[Meknes]] and Colonel [[Noël Garnier-Duplessix]] from [[Kasbah Tadla]].{{cite book| last = Hoisington| first = William A| title = Lyautey and the French Conquest of Morocco| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iBn1PHEGGokC| year = 1995| publisher = Macmillan:St Martin's Press| isbn = 0-312-12529-1| page = 66| place = New York }}{{cite book| last = Lyautey| first = Louis Hubert Gonzalve| title = Lyautey l'africain: textes et lettres du maréchal Lyautey, Volume 2| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xaxyAAAAMAAJ| year = 1954| publisher = Plon| language = French| pages = 187 & 196 }} == First World War == [[File:Cros national.png|thumb|A wounded Cros directs his men from a horsedrawn carriage as drawn in a contemporary issue of ''L'Illustré National'']] After the outbreak of the [[First World War]] Cros returned to France from Africa, with the 8th Marching Regiment (an [[ad hoc]] unit made up of tirailleurs and [[zouave]]s).{{cite web|last=Boÿ|first=Général de brigade Jean|title=Historique de la 66e promotion de l'Ecole spéciale militaire de Saint-Cyr (1881–1883), promotion d'Egypte|url=http://www.saint-cyr.org/fichiers/promotions-eteintes/1881-1883-66e-promotion-d-egypte.pdf|publisher=Association des élèves et anciens élèves de l'école spéciale militaire de Saint-Cyr|accessdate=29 December 2012|language=French}}{{cite book| last = Recouly| first = Raymond| title = Foch, the winner of the war| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wK8EAAAAYAAJ| year = 1920| publisher = C. Scribner's Sons| page = 91 }}{{cite journal|last=Heuzey|first=Léon|title=Éloge funèbre de M. le commandant Gaston Cros, tué à l'ennemi|journal=Comptes-rendus des séances de l'Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres|date=2 July 1915|volume=59|issue=4|pages=244–5|url=http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/crai_0065-0536_1915_num_59_4_73567|accessdate=29 December 2012|language=French}} His unit was sent to defend [[Paris]] in the [[First Battle of the Marne]] where it was ordered to take the town of [[Saint-Prix, Val-d'Oise|Saint-Prix]], which changed hands five times in the first four days of the battle.{{cite book|last=Horne|first=Charles F.|title=The Great Events of the Great War Part Two|year=1923|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=48JtX6i1o3gC}}{{cite book| last = Recouly| first = Raymond| title = Foch, the winner of the war| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wK8EAAAAYAAJ| year = 1920| publisher = C. Scribner's Sons| page = 104 }} The move was intended to clear the way for the [[42nd Infantry Division (France)|42nd Infantry Division]] to advance on Cros' left. He was wounded in the leg in an action at [[Mondement-Montgivroux]] on 9 September that earned him a [[mention in dispatches]] and, later, his description as "bravest of the brave". After two days spent following his unit in a horse-drawn carriage he was forced to leave his command.{{cite web|last=Charvát|first=Petr|title=Dějiny archeologických výzkumů na Blízkém Východě|url=http://www.zcu.cz/ff/kbs/files/2012/DAV2.doc|publisher=Západočeská univerzita v Plzni (Pilsen University, Czech republic)|accessdate=29 December 2012|language=Czech}} On 15 September Cros received temporary promotion to colonel and on 20 October was given command of the 2nd Moroccan Brigade at the [[Battle of the Yser]]. His promotion was confirmed as permanent on 1 November 1914 and he became a commander of the Legion of Honour on 10 April 1915. He also received a further mention in dispatches as "a brave soldier, an experienced great leader, wise, prudent, with natural authority" and was awarded the [[Croix de Guerre]] with palm. In the spring he wrote to an archaeological colleague, [[Léon Heuzey]], telling him that "I continue with my work as an archaeologist. As at Tello I record earthworks, but instead of artefacts of [[Gudea]] I find German shells, it is not without excitement". Cros was appointed a commander of the Legion of Honour on 10 April 1915.{{cite web|title=Legion of Honour records - page 3|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v003.htm|work=Base Léonore|publisher=Ministère de la Culture|accessdate=3 February 2013}} [[File:Vimy Ridge - Moroccan Division Memorial.jpg|thumb|left|The Vimy Ridge Moroccan Division Memorial bearing Cros' name]] Later that year Cros led his brigade, as part of the [[1st Moroccan Infantry Division]], at the [[Second Battle of Artois]] - an allied attempt to capture [[Vimy Ridge]] with an assault on a {{convert|13|mi|km}} wide stretch of the front.{{cite book| last = Geraghty| first = Tony| title = March Or Die: France and the Foreign Legion| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=n5kyh80JjcgC| year = 2001| publisher = Harper Collins| location = London| isbn = 0-00-653174-1| pages = 161–163 }} Cros took particular care to inspire a keen [[esprit de corps]] in his men and on the eve of the attack told them: "I am your father and you know that I love you as my children, if you want to show me that you love me in return, fight and kill lots of Boche".{{cite book| last = Meynier| first = Gilbert| title = L'Algérie révélée: La guerre de 1914–1918 et le premier quart du XXe siècle| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Us_7F_9JfhcC| year = 1981| publisher = Librairie Droz| location = Geneva| language = French| isbn = 978-2-600-04098-3| page = 440 }} At 10 AM on 9 May 1915 Cros' brigade advanced in conjunction with the division's 1st Brigade, a [[French Foreign Legion]] unit led by [[Colonel Pein]]. The five-hour preliminary bombardment was largely ineffective and the division took heavy casualties in reaching the German lines, {{convert|3|mi|km}} distant. However they managed to push the Germans out and some units even reached the villages of [[Vimy]] and [[Givenchy-en-Gohelle]]. The next morning, hit by their own artillery and under German counter-attack, the French were forced to withdraw to their own lines in the course of which Cros was killed. Cros was one of almost 2,000 men of the Moroccan division killed in that action, as was fellow brigade commander Colonel Pein. Cros' colleague Huezey described him later as "a trainer of men and a keen naturalist whose integrity was matched by his intelligence and bravery. His medals and uniform are held in the collection of the [[Musée zoologique de la ville de Strasbourg]] and he is remembered in the inscription on the [[Moroccan Division Memorial]] at Vimy.{{cite web|title=Chromamix I|url=http://www.musees-strasbourg.org/sites_expos/CHROMAMIX1/RESOURCES_CRHO/visuels_chroma.pdf|publisher=Musée Zoologique de la Ville de Strasbourg|accessdate=29 December 2012|language=French}} {{Quotation|To the fallen of the Moroccan Division
Without fear, without mercy

To the memory of Colonel Pein, Commander of the 1st Brigade, of Colonel Cros, commander of the 2nd Brigade, officers, non-commissioned officers and soldiers of the Moroccan Division who gloriously gave their lives on 9, 10 and 11 May 1915. On 9 May 1915, the regiments of the Moroccan Division at 10AM launched their offensive from the Berthonval trenches and successfully overcame fierce resistance from the German side to claim victory over Hill 140, their objective - breaking through enemy lines for the very first time| Translation of the inscription on the [[Moroccan Division Memorial]] at Vimy.{{cite web|title=Algeria, Egypt, Morocco and Tunisia 1914–1919|url=http://www.forgottenheroes.eu/EN_LR.pdf|work=Forgotten Heroes North Africans and the Great War 1914–1919|publisher=Forgotten heroes 14-19 foundation|accessdate=29 December 2012}} }} == References == {{Research help|Mil}} {{Reflist}} {{good article}} ==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Gaston Cros}} * [http://www.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH048/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL0634013v001.htm Legion of Honour] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cros, Gaston}} [[Category:1861 births]] [[Category:1915 deaths]] [[Category:French Army officers]] [[Category:French archaeologists]] [[Category:French military personnel killed in World War I]] [[Category:Commandeurs of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Recipients of the Croix de guerre 1914–1918 (France)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Dragon of Annam]] [[Category:Ordre des Palmes Académiques recipients]]
